SENT.plain: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF), which often precedes permanent AF, is reported to be a risk factor for milder ischemic stroke
We assessed whether the type of AF and prestroke treatment with an anticoagulant were associated with physical disabilities in patients with AF-related acute ischemic stroke
We identified 162 consecutive acute ischemic stroke patients with AF who were admitted to our hospital over a 3-year period
Disability was measured using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) at the time of discharge and was categorized according to favorable clinical outcome (mRS score 0-2)
Of the 162 patients, 71 (43.8%) had paroxysmal AF and 91 had permanent AF
Fifty-six patients (34.6%) had been treated with a prophylactic anticoagulant
A total of 103 patients (63.6%) had a favorable outcome

Multivariate logistic analysis revealed that paroxysmal AF (odds ratio [OR], 1.58; P = .0187), prestroke anticoagulation treatment (OR, 1.95; P = .0019), and noncardiogenic embolism (OR, 2.20; P = .0073) were independent factors associated with a favorable clinical outcome
Our data indicate that paroxysmal AF and prestroke anticoagulation treatment are independently associated with favorable clinical outcome at the time of hospital discharge in patients with AF
